nexttext:
The remaining bosonic generators, having the proper form in the flat limit, may be defined as follows:
\begin{eqnarray}\label{newgen}
&& P, \quad Z=P_{11}-P_{22}-2 {\rm i} P_{12}+{\rm i} \frac{m}{4} \left( M_{11}-M_{22}-2 {\rm i} M_{12} \right),\; {\overline Z}{}= \left(Z\right)^\dagger, {\nonumber} \\
&& J_3 = \frac{{\rm i}}{4} \left( M_{11}+M_{22}\right), \quad T =\frac{{\rm i}}{4}\left( M_{11}-M_{22} -2 {\rm i} M_{12}\right), \;
{\overline T}{}=\left( T\right)^\dagger.
\end{eqnarray}

Thus, the bosonic part of the algebra {(\ref{{ads3}})}, i.e. the algebra $so(2,2) \times u(1)$, acquires the form:
\begin{eqnarray}\label{bosAdS}
&& \left[J_3, T\right]= T, \; \left[J_3, {\overline T}{}\right]= -{\overline T}{}, \; \left[T, {\overline T}{}\right]= -2 J_3 , {\nonumber} \\
&& \left[ P, Z\right]= 2 m Z, \; \left[P, {\overline Z}{}\right]= - 2 m {\overline Z}{}, \; \left[Z, {\overline Z}{}\right]= -4 m P +4 m^2 J , {\nonumber} \\
&& \left[J_3, Z\right] =Z, \; \left[ J_3, {\overline Z}{}\right]= - {\overline Z}{} , {\nonumber} \\
&& \left[T, P\right] =-Z, \; \left[{\overline T}{},P\right] ={\overline Z}{},\quad
\left[ T, {\overline Z}{}\right]= - 2 P +2 m J,\;  \left[ {\overline T}{}, Z\right]=  2 P - 2 m J .
\end{eqnarray}
Clearly, the relations {(\ref{{bosAdS}})} are maximally similar to the $D=3$ Poincar\'{e} ones we used in \cite{kkln} and go
to them in the limit $m=0$ (with decoupled generator $J$, of course).

As concerning the fermionic part of $N=(2,0)$ AdS$_3$ superalgebra {(\ref{{ads3}})},  it is natural to define the generators of broken supersymmetry as

nexttext:
which look much more complicated than in the flat space-time $(m \rightarrow 0)$ \cite{kkln}
\begin{eqnarray}\label{CF1}
&& \Omega_P = \frac{1}{1-{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}{\boldsymbol{\bar\lambda}}}\left[ \left(1+{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}{\boldsymbol{\bar\lambda}}\right) {\hat\Omega}_P - 2 {\rm i} \left( {\boldsymbol{\bar\lambda}} {\hat\Omega}_Z-{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}  {\hat{ {\overline \Omega}{}}}_Z\right)\right], \quad \Omega_Q = \frac{\hat\Omega_Q - {\rm i} {\boldsymbol{\bar\lambda}} \hat{{\overline \Omega}{}}_S}{\sqrt{1-{\boldsymbol{\lambda}} {\boldsymbol{\bar\lambda}}}},
{\nonumber} \[2mm]
&& \Omega_Z = \frac{1}{1-{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}{\boldsymbol{\bar\lambda}}}\left[{\hat\Omega}_Z -{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}^2 {\hat{ {\overline \Omega}{}}}_Z +{\rm i} {\boldsymbol{\lambda}} {\hat\Omega}_P\right],\;\Omega_J = {\hat\Omega}_J -\frac{1}{1-{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}{\boldsymbol{\bar\lambda}}}\left[ 2 m {\boldsymbol{\lambda}}{\boldsymbol{\bar\lambda}} {\hat\Omega}_P - 2 {\rm i} m \left( {\boldsymbol{\bar\lambda}} {\hat\Omega}_Z-{\boldsymbol{\lambda}} {\hat{{\overline \Omega}{}}}_Z\right)\right], {\nonumber} \[2mm]
&& \Omega_T = \frac{d{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}}{1-{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}{\boldsymbol{\bar\lambda}}}, \quad
\Omega_3 = {\rm i}\frac{{\boldsymbol{\lambda}} d{\boldsymbol{\bar\lambda}}-d{\boldsymbol{\lambda}} {\boldsymbol{\bar\lambda}}}{1-{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}{\boldsymbol{\bar\lambda}}},  \quad \Omega_S = \frac{\hat\Omega_S - {\rm i} {\boldsymbol{\bar\lambda}} \hat{{\overline \Omega}{}}_Q}{\sqrt{1-{\boldsymbol{\lambda}} {\boldsymbol{\bar\lambda}}}},
\end{eqnarray}
where the hatted forms read
\begin{eqnarray}\label{hatCF}
\hat{\Omega}_P &=& \frac{\left( 1+4m^2 {\mathbf{u}}{\mathbf{\bar u}}  \right)\hat\triangle t +2{\rm i} m \left( {\mathbf{u}} d{\mathbf{\bar u}}  - {\mathbf{\bar u}} d{\mathbf{u}}  \right) +8m \left(   {\mathbf{u}}{\boldsymbol{\psi}} d\theta - {\mathbf{\bar u}} {\bar{\boldsymbol{\psi}}} d\bar\theta \right)}{1-4m^2 {\mathbf{u}}{\mathbf{\bar u}}}, {\nonumber} \\
\hat{\Omega}_Z &=& \frac{d{\mathbf{u}} +2{\rm i} m {\mathbf{u}} \hat\triangle t - 2{\rm i} \left( {\bar{\boldsymbol{\psi}}} d\bar\theta - 4m^2 {\mathbf{u}}^2 {\boldsymbol{\psi}} d\theta  \right)}{1-4m^2 {\mathbf{u}}{\mathbf{\bar u}}},{\nonumber} \\
\hat\Omega_J &=& -\frac{8m^3 {\mathbf{u}}{\mathbf{\bar u}} }{1-4m^2 {\mathbf{u}}{\mathbf{\bar u}}} \hat\triangle t +2{\rm i} m^2 \frac{{\mathbf{\bar u}} d{\mathbf{u}} - d{\mathbf{\bar u}} {\mathbf{u}}}{1-4m^2 {\mathbf{u}}{\mathbf{\bar u}}} - 8 \frac{m^2 \left( {\mathbf{u}}{\boldsymbol{\psi}} d\theta - {\mathbf{\bar u}} {\bar{\boldsymbol{\psi}}} d\bar\theta  \right)}{1-4m^2 {\mathbf{u}}{\mathbf{\bar u}}} {\nonumber} \\
&& -8 m^2 \left[ dt -{\rm i} \left( \theta d\bar\theta + \bar\theta d\theta\right) \right] {\boldsymbol{\psi}} {\bar{\boldsymbol{\psi}}} +2 {\rm i} m \left(  {\boldsymbol{\psi}} d{\bar{\boldsymbol{\psi}}}  + {\bar{\boldsymbol{\psi}}} d{\boldsymbol{\psi}}  \right) {\nonumber} \\
&=& 2 m \left[ dt -{\rm i} \left( \theta d\bar\theta + \bar\theta d\theta\right) \right] - m \hat\triangle t - m \hat\Omega_P, {\nonumber} \\
\hat\Omega_Q & = & \frac{\triangle \theta - 2{\rm i} m {\mathbf{\bar u}} \triangle {\bar{\boldsymbol{\psi}}}}{\sqrt{1-4 m^2 {\mathbf{u}}{\mathbf{\bar u}} }}, \quad
\hat\Omega_S  =  \frac{\triangle {\boldsymbol{\psi}} - 2{\rm i} m {\mathbf{\bar u}} \triangle \bar\theta}{\sqrt{1-4 m^2 {\mathbf{u}}{\mathbf{\bar u}} }}.
\end{eqnarray}
Here,
\begin{eqnarray}\label{diff}
\hat\triangle t &=& \left(1+4m {\boldsymbol{\psi}}{\bar{\boldsymbol{\psi}}}   \right) \left[ dt -{\rm i} \left( \theta d\bar\theta + \bar\theta d\theta+{\boldsymbol{\psi}} d{\bar{\boldsymbol{\psi}}}  + {\bar{\boldsymbol{\psi}}} d{\boldsymbol{\psi}}\right) \right] \equiv
\left(1+4m {\boldsymbol{\psi}}{\bar{\boldsymbol{\psi}}}   \right) \triangle t,{\nonumber} \\
\triangle\theta & = & \left(  1 -2m {\boldsymbol{\psi}}{\bar{\boldsymbol{\psi}}}    \right)d\theta, \quad \triangle {\boldsymbol{\psi}} = d{\boldsymbol{\psi}} - 2{\rm i} m {\boldsymbol{\psi}} \left[ dt -{\rm i} \left( \theta d\bar\theta + \bar\theta d\theta\right) \right] .
\end{eqnarray}

In what follows, we find it convenient to define the covariant derivatives similarly to the flat case, i.e.   with respect to differentials $\triangle t, d\theta, d\bar\theta$:

prevtext:
which look much more complicated than in the flat space-time $(m \rightarrow 0)$ \cite{kkln}
\begin{eqnarray}\label{CF1}
&& \Omega_P = \frac{1}{1-{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}{\boldsymbol{\bar\lambda}}}\left[ \left(1+{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}{\boldsymbol{\bar\lambda}}\right) {\hat\Omega}_P - 2 {\rm i} \left( {\boldsymbol{\bar\lambda}} {\hat\Omega}_Z-{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}  {\hat{ {\overline \Omega}{}}}_Z\right)\right], \quad \Omega_Q = \frac{\hat\Omega_Q - {\rm i} {\boldsymbol{\bar\lambda}} \hat{{\overline \Omega}{}}_S}{\sqrt{1-{\boldsymbol{\lambda}} {\boldsymbol{\bar\lambda}}}},
{\nonumber} \[2mm]
&& \Omega_Z = \frac{1}{1-{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}{\boldsymbol{\bar\lambda}}}\left[{\hat\Omega}_Z -{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}^2 {\hat{ {\overline \Omega}{}}}_Z +{\rm i} {\boldsymbol{\lambda}} {\hat\Omega}_P\right],\;\Omega_J = {\hat\Omega}_J -\frac{1}{1-{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}{\boldsymbol{\bar\lambda}}}\left[ 2 m {\boldsymbol{\lambda}}{\boldsymbol{\bar\lambda}} {\hat\Omega}_P - 2 {\rm i} m \left( {\boldsymbol{\bar\lambda}} {\hat\Omega}_Z-{\boldsymbol{\lambda}} {\hat{{\overline \Omega}{}}}_Z\right)\right], {\nonumber} \[2mm]
&& \Omega_T = \frac{d{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}}{1-{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}{\boldsymbol{\bar\lambda}}}, \quad
\Omega_3 = {\rm i}\frac{{\boldsymbol{\lambda}} d{\boldsymbol{\bar\lambda}}-d{\boldsymbol{\lambda}} {\boldsymbol{\bar\lambda}}}{1-{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}{\boldsymbol{\bar\lambda}}},  \quad \Omega_S = \frac{\hat\Omega_S - {\rm i} {\boldsymbol{\bar\lambda}} \hat{{\overline \Omega}{}}_Q}{\sqrt{1-{\boldsymbol{\lambda}} {\boldsymbol{\bar\lambda}}}},
\end{eqnarray}
where the hatted forms read
\begin{eqnarray}\label{hatCF}
\hat{\Omega}_P &=& \frac{\left( 1+4m^2 {\mathbf{u}}{\mathbf{\bar u}}  \right)\hat\triangle t +2{\rm i} m \left( {\mathbf{u}} d{\mathbf{\bar u}}  - {\mathbf{\bar u}} d{\mathbf{u}}  \right) +8m \left(   {\mathbf{u}}{\boldsymbol{\psi}} d\theta - {\mathbf{\bar u}} {\bar{\boldsymbol{\psi}}} d\bar\theta \right)}{1-4m^2 {\mathbf{u}}{\mathbf{\bar u}}}, {\nonumber} \\
\hat{\Omega}_Z &=& \frac{d{\mathbf{u}} +2{\rm i} m {\mathbf{u}} \hat\triangle t - 2{\rm i} \left( {\bar{\boldsymbol{\psi}}} d\bar\theta - 4m^2 {\mathbf{u}}^2 {\boldsymbol{\psi}} d\theta  \right)}{1-4m^2 {\mathbf{u}}{\mathbf{\bar u}}},{\nonumber} \\
\hat\Omega_J &=& -\frac{8m^3 {\mathbf{u}}{\mathbf{\bar u}} }{1-4m^2 {\mathbf{u}}{\mathbf{\bar u}}} \hat\triangle t +2{\rm i} m^2 \frac{{\mathbf{\bar u}} d{\mathbf{u}} - d{\mathbf{\bar u}} {\mathbf{u}}}{1-4m^2 {\mathbf{u}}{\mathbf{\bar u}}} - 8 \frac{m^2 \left( {\mathbf{u}}{\boldsymbol{\psi}} d\theta - {\mathbf{\bar u}} {\bar{\boldsymbol{\psi}}} d\bar\theta  \right)}{1-4m^2 {\mathbf{u}}{\mathbf{\bar u}}} {\nonumber} \\
&& -8 m^2 \left[ dt -{\rm i} \left( \theta d\bar\theta + \bar\theta d\theta\right) \right] {\boldsymbol{\psi}} {\bar{\boldsymbol{\psi}}} +2 {\rm i} m \left(  {\boldsymbol{\psi}} d{\bar{\boldsymbol{\psi}}}  + {\bar{\boldsymbol{\psi}}} d{\boldsymbol{\psi}}  \right) {\nonumber} \\
&=& 2 m \left[ dt -{\rm i} \left( \theta d\bar\theta + \bar\theta d\theta\right) \right] - m \hat\triangle t - m \hat\Omega_P, {\nonumber} \\
\hat\Omega_Q & = & \frac{\triangle \theta - 2{\rm i} m {\mathbf{\bar u}} \triangle {\bar{\boldsymbol{\psi}}}}{\sqrt{1-4 m^2 {\mathbf{u}}{\mathbf{\bar u}} }}, \quad
\hat\Omega_S  =  \frac{\triangle {\boldsymbol{\psi}} - 2{\rm i} m {\mathbf{\bar u}} \triangle \bar\theta}{\sqrt{1-4 m^2 {\mathbf{u}}{\mathbf{\bar u}} }}.
\end{eqnarray}
Here,
\begin{eqnarray}\label{diff}
\hat\triangle t &=& \left(1+4m {\boldsymbol{\psi}}{\bar{\boldsymbol{\psi}}}   \right) \left[ dt -{\rm i} \left( \theta d\bar\theta + \bar\theta d\theta+{\boldsymbol{\psi}} d{\bar{\boldsymbol{\psi}}}  + {\bar{\boldsymbol{\psi}}} d{\boldsymbol{\psi}}\right) \right] \equiv
\left(1+4m {\boldsymbol{\psi}}{\bar{\boldsymbol{\psi}}}   \right) \triangle t,{\nonumber} \\
\triangle\theta & = & \left(  1 -2m {\boldsymbol{\psi}}{\bar{\boldsymbol{\psi}}}    \right)d\theta, \quad \triangle {\boldsymbol{\psi}} = d{\boldsymbol{\psi}} - 2{\rm i} m {\boldsymbol{\psi}} \left[ dt -{\rm i} \left( \theta d\bar\theta + \bar\theta d\theta\right) \right] .
\end{eqnarray}

In what follows, we find it convenient to define the covariant derivatives similarly to the flat case, i.e.   with respect to differentials $\triangle t, d\theta, d\bar\theta$:

In principle,  {(\ref{{IC1}})}, {(\ref{{IC21}})}, {(\ref{{IC22}})} solve all tasks. Indeed, using {(\ref{{IC1}})} one may
express the superfields ${\boldsymbol{\lambda}}, {\boldsymbol{\bar\lambda}}$ in terms of  time derivatives of  ${\mathbf{u}},{\mathbf{\bar u}}$, while {(\ref{{IC21}})} can be solved to express the fermionic superfields  ${\boldsymbol{\psi}}, {\bar{\boldsymbol{\psi}}}$ in terms of spinor covariant
derivatives of the same ${\mathbf{u}},{\mathbf{\bar u}}$. Thus, like in the flat case \cite{kkln}, we remain with only one $N=2$ complex bosonic superfield ${\mathbf{u}}(t, \theta, \bar\theta)$, restricted by  {(\ref{{IC21}})} to be
covariantly chiral, with slightly modified chirality conditions. However, in what follows we are going to use as
independent components the $\theta=\bar\theta=0$ projections of the superfields ${\boldsymbol{\psi}}, {\bar{\boldsymbol{\psi}}}$ instead of the
projections of $ {\overline \nabla} {\mathbf{u}}$ and $\nabla {\mathbf{\bar u}}$. Therefore, it would be
useful to find the consequences of the constraints {(\ref{{IC1}})}, {(\ref{{IC21}})}, {(\ref{{IC22}})}.

First of all, acting by $\nabla$ on the first equation in {(\ref{{IC21}})} and by ${\overline \nabla}$ on the second one and using the algebra {(\ref{{CDcom}})} of the covariant derivatives, we get the conditions

where $X$ is  some expression which is defined by this equation. The main difference between {(\ref{{Alt1}})} and
{(\ref{{Alt2}})} is that the latter one is written as the equation on  forms. Therefore, one may just substitute in {(\ref{{Alt2}})}
the exact expressions from {(\ref{{hatCF}})} and equate on both sides the coefficients of the differentials $\triangle t, d \theta$
and $d\bar\theta$. The $\triangle t$ coefficient relation yields $X$ in terms of $\nabla_t {\boldsymbol{\psi}}$.
Substituting this expression for $X$ in the $d\theta, d\bar\theta$ -projections of {(\ref{{Alt2}})} we immediately
obtain the first equation in {(\ref{{IC31}})} and also {(\ref{{IC33}})}. The same procedure applied to the second constraint in {(\ref{{Alt1}})} produces the second equation in {(\ref{{IC31}})} as well as {(\ref{{IC32}})}.

These considerations demonstrate that the constraints {(\ref{{Alt1}})} are a consequence of our basic constraints {(\ref{{SUSYih}})}.

\noindent{\it Unbroken $Q$ supersymmetry}\\
The  transformations under unbroken $Q$-supersymmetry can be defined in a usual way as
\begin{eqnarray}\label{Qtrgen}
\delta_Q f &=& - \big( \epsilon D + \bar\epsilon{\overline D}{}   \big){\mathbf{f}} |_{\theta\rightarrow 0} =  - \big( \epsilon \nabla + \bar\epsilon{\overline \nabla}  \big){\mathbf{f}} |_{\theta\rightarrow 0} - H \partial_t, {\nonumber} \\
H &=& {\rm i} \epsilon \big( {\boldsymbol{\psi}} \nabla{\bar{\boldsymbol{\psi}}}  + {\bar{\boldsymbol{\psi}}} \nabla{\boldsymbol{\psi}} \big) |_{\theta\rightarrow 0} + {\rm i} \bar\epsilon \big( {\boldsymbol{\psi}} {\overline \nabla}{\bar{\boldsymbol{\psi}}}  + {\bar{\boldsymbol{\psi}}} {\overline \nabla}{\boldsymbol{\psi}} \big) |_{\theta\rightarrow 0}.
\end{eqnarray}
For example,

 +4 m { {\cal E}   } \big( \epsilon {\cal D}_t \psi u - \bar\epsilon {\cal D}_t {\bar\psi}{} \bar u   \big)\frac{1 - \lambda \bar\lambda}{1+\lambda \bar\lambda +2m \big( u\bar\lambda + \bar u\lambda   \big) }  {\nonumber} \\
-4 {\rm i} m { {\cal E}   } \epsilon\psi \frac{\big(1 -\lambda\bar\lambda \big)\big( 1+ 2m  u\bar\lambda  \big)\big(\lambda + 2 m u)}{\big[1 +\lambda\bar\lambda+ 2m \big(u\bar\lambda + \bar u \lambda \big) \big]^2} - 4 {\rm i} m { {\cal E}   } \bar \epsilon{\bar\psi}{} \frac{\big(1 -\lambda\bar\lambda \big)\big( 1+ 2m  \bar u\lambda  \big)\big(\bar\lambda + 2 m \bar u)}{\big[1 +\lambda\bar\lambda+ 2m \big(u\bar\lambda + \bar u \lambda \big) \big]^2}.

$$

nexttext:
and then taking the limit $\omega \rightarrow \infty$.  After performing of this step, we will finish with the following
algebra
\begin{eqnarray}\label{NHooke}
&& \big[ J_3 , T  \big] = T, \; \big[ J_3 , {\overline T}{}    \big] = -{\overline T}{}, \quad \big[ J_3, Z \big] = Z, \; \big[ J_3, {\overline Z}{} \big] = - {\overline Z}{}, {\nonumber} \\
&& \big[ P, Z \big] =2 m Z, \quad \big[ P, {\overline Z}{} \big] = -2 m{\overline Z}{}, \quad \big[ T, P \big] = -Z , \quad \big[ {\overline T}{}, P\big] = {\overline Z}{} .
\end{eqnarray}
Clearly, the generator $J$ is decoupled from the algebra while $J_3$ generates outer automorphisms.

The algebra {(\ref{{NHooke}})} is just the Newton-Hooke algebra \cite{NH1,NH2}. To bring the commutation relations to the conventional
form \cite{GP, ABGR, BGKPRZ} one has to redefine the generators as follows,
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E46.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="Z\rightarrow\omega Z,\;{\overline{Z}}{}\rightarrow\omega{\overline{Z}}{},\;T%
\rightarrow\omega T,\;{\overline{T}}{}\rightarrow\omega{\overline{T}}{}." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mi>Z</mi><mo>→</mo><mrow><mi>ω</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>Z</mi></mrow></mrow><mo rspace="5.3pt">,</mo><mrow><mrow><mover accent="true"><mi>Z</mi><mo>¯</mo></mover><mo>→</mo><mrow><mi>ω</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mover accent="true"><mi>Z</mi><mo>¯</mo></mover></mrow></mrow><mo rspace="5.3pt">,</mo><mrow><mrow><mi>T</mi><mo>→</mo><mrow><mi>ω</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>T</mi></mrow></mrow><mo rspace="5.3pt">,</mo><mrow><mover accent="true"><mi>T</mi><mo>¯</mo></mover><mo>→</mo><mrow><mi>ω</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mover accent="true"><mi>T</mi><mo>¯</mo></mover></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

Again, after taking the limit $\omega \rightarrow \infty$, we obtain the following commutation relations,
\begin{eqnarray}\label{newNHooke}
&&  \big[ T, P \big] = -Z , \quad \big[ {\overline T}{}, P\big] = {\overline Z}{}, \quad \big[ P, Z \big] =2 m Z, \quad \big[ P, {\overline Z}{} \big] = -2 m{\overline Z}{},   {\nonumber} \\
&& \big[ T, {\overline T}{}  \big] =-2J_3,\quad \big[ T,{\overline Z}{}\big] = 2 m J, \quad \big[ {\overline T}{}, Z \big] =-2m J, \quad \big[ Z,{\overline Z}{}\big] = 4 m^2 J.
\end{eqnarray}
Now both generators $J$ and $J_3$ become  central elements in the algebra {(\ref{{newNHooke}})}. Moreover, the $U(1)$ rotations
generated previously by the generator $J_3$ disappeared from the algebra. Clearly, the corresponding generator $V_3$ with

prevtext:
Again, after taking the limit $\omega \rightarrow \infty$, we obtain the following commutation relations,
\begin{eqnarray}\label{newNHooke}
&&  \big[ T, P \big] = -Z , \quad \big[ {\overline T}{}, P\big] = {\overline Z}{}, \quad \big[ P, Z \big] =2 m Z, \quad \big[ P, {\overline Z}{} \big] = -2 m{\overline Z}{},   {\nonumber} \\
&& \big[ T, {\overline T}{}  \big] =-2J_3,\quad \big[ T,{\overline Z}{}\big] = 2 m J, \quad \big[ {\overline T}{}, Z \big] =-2m J, \quad \big[ Z,{\overline Z}{}\big] = 4 m^2 J.
\end{eqnarray}
Now both generators $J$ and $J_3$ become  central elements in the algebra {(\ref{{newNHooke}})}. Moreover, the $U(1)$ rotations
generated previously by the generator $J_3$ disappeared from the algebra. Clearly, the corresponding generator $V_3$ with
the relations

Keeping in the mind that the action $\int \omega_P = \int dt$ is trivial, we have  three possible invariant actions:
\begin{eqnarray}\label{redact}
&& S_0^{bos} = \frac{1}{2m} \int \omega_J =\int dt \left[ \dot{u} \dot{{\bar u}} - {\rm i} m \left( \dot{u} {\bar u} - u \dot{{\bar u}} \right) \right], \\
&& S_{anyon}^{bos} =- \int \omega_3 =  \int dt \left\{ {\rm i} \left[ \ddot{u}\dot{{\bar u}} -\dot{u}\ddot{{\bar u}} + 4 m^2\left( \dot{u} {\bar u} -u \dot{{\bar u}}\right)\right] - 8 m \dot{u} \dot{{\bar u}} \right\},\\
&& S_{rigid}^{bos} = \int \frac{\omega_T {\bar\omega}_T}{\omega_P} =  \int dt \left[ \ddot{u} \ddot{{\bar u}} - 2 {\rm i} m \left( \ddot{u}\dot{{\bar u}} -\dot{u} \ddot{{\bar u}}\right)+
4 m^2 \dot{u} \dot{{\bar u}} \right].
\end{eqnarray}

With such a coset element the Cartan forms are simplified to
\begin{eqnarray}\label{SUSYNHooke-forms2}
\omega_P & = & \triangle t = dt - {\rm i} \big( \theta d\bar\theta + \bar\theta d \theta \big), \quad \omega_Q = d\theta, \quad
\omega_T = d{\boldsymbol{\lambda}},  \;
 \omega_3 = {\rm i} \big( {\boldsymbol{\lambda}} d{\boldsymbol{\bar\lambda}} - {\boldsymbol{\bar\lambda}} d {\boldsymbol{\lambda}}  \big),  {\nonumber} \\
\omega_Z & = & d {\mathbf{u}}  + {\rm i} \big(2m {\mathbf{u}} + {\boldsymbol{\lambda}} \big) \triangle t -2{\rm i} {\bar{\boldsymbol{\psi}}} d\bar\theta, \quad
\omega_S  =  d{\boldsymbol{\psi}} -2 {\rm i} m {\boldsymbol{\psi}} \triangle t     -{\rm i} \big(  2 m {\mathbf{\bar u}} + {\boldsymbol{\bar\lambda}} \big)d\bar\theta,  {\nonumber} \\
\omega_J &=& 2{\rm i} m \big( {\bar{\boldsymbol{\psi}}} d {\boldsymbol{\psi}} + {\boldsymbol{\psi}} d{\bar{\boldsymbol{\psi}}}    \big) - 8 m^2 {\boldsymbol{\psi}}{\bar{\boldsymbol{\psi}}} \triangle t - 8 m^2 \big( {\mathbf{u}} {\boldsymbol{\psi}} d\theta - {\mathbf{\bar u}} {\bar{\boldsymbol{\psi}}} d\bar\theta \big) - 8 m^3 {\mathbf{u}} {\mathbf{\bar u}} \triangle t  -2 m {\boldsymbol{\lambda}} {\boldsymbol{\bar\lambda}} \triangle t {\nonumber} \\
&& -2{\rm i} m {\boldsymbol{\lambda}} \big(d {\mathbf{\bar u}}  - 2 {\rm i} m {\mathbf{\bar u}} \triangle t -2{\rm i} {\boldsymbol{\psi}} d\theta      \big) +2 {\rm i} m {\boldsymbol{\bar\lambda}} \big(  d {\mathbf{u}}  + 2 {\rm i} m {\mathbf{u}} \triangle t -2{\rm i} {\bar{\boldsymbol{\psi}}} d\bar\theta  \big)  -2{\rm i} m^2 \big( {\mathbf{u}} d{\mathbf{\bar u}} - {\mathbf{\bar u}} d{\mathbf{u}}    \big).
\end{eqnarray}

\omega_Z & = & d {\mathbf{u}}  + {\rm i} \big(2m {\mathbf{u}} + {\boldsymbol{\lambda}} \big) \triangle t -2{\rm i} {\bar{\boldsymbol{\psi}}} d\bar\theta, \quad
\omega_S  =  d{\boldsymbol{\psi}} -2 {\rm i} m {\boldsymbol{\psi}} \triangle t     -{\rm i} \big(  2 m {\mathbf{\bar u}} + {\boldsymbol{\bar\lambda}} \big)d\bar\theta,  {\nonumber} \\
\omega_J &=& 2{\rm i} m \big( {\bar{\boldsymbol{\psi}}} d {\boldsymbol{\psi}} + {\boldsymbol{\psi}} d{\bar{\boldsymbol{\psi}}}    \big) - 8 m^2 {\boldsymbol{\psi}}{\bar{\boldsymbol{\psi}}} \triangle t - 8 m^2 \big( {\mathbf{u}} {\boldsymbol{\psi}} d\theta - {\mathbf{\bar u}} {\bar{\boldsymbol{\psi}}} d\bar\theta \big) - 8 m^3 {\mathbf{u}} {\mathbf{\bar u}} \triangle t  -2 m {\boldsymbol{\lambda}} {\boldsymbol{\bar\lambda}} \triangle t {\nonumber} \\
&& -2{\rm i} m {\boldsymbol{\lambda}} \big(d {\mathbf{\bar u}}  - 2 {\rm i} m {\mathbf{\bar u}} \triangle t -2{\rm i} {\boldsymbol{\psi}} d\theta      \big) +2 {\rm i} m {\boldsymbol{\bar\lambda}} \big(  d {\mathbf{u}}  + 2 {\rm i} m {\mathbf{u}} \triangle t -2{\rm i} {\bar{\boldsymbol{\psi}}} d\bar\theta  \big)  -2{\rm i} m^2 \big( {\mathbf{u}} d{\mathbf{\bar u}} - {\mathbf{\bar u}} d{\mathbf{u}}    \big).
\end{eqnarray}
Imposing the standard conditions of the inverse Higgs effect {(\ref{{ih}})},
text: $$\omega_Z =0, \, \bar\omega_Z = 0,$$
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex9.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\omega_{Z}=0,\,\bar{\omega}_{Z}=0," display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><msub><mi>ω</mi><mi>Z</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow><mo rspace="4.2pt">,</mo><mrow><msub><mover accent="true"><mi>ω</mi><mo stretchy="false">¯</mo></mover><mi>Z</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></math>

prevtext:
we get the equations
\begin{eqnarray}
&& D {\mathbf{u}} =0, \quad {\overline D}{} {\mathbf{\bar u}} =0, \label{chir} \\
&& {\boldsymbol{\psi}} = \frac{{\rm i}}{2} D{\mathbf{\bar u}},\; {\bar{\boldsymbol{\psi}}} = \frac{{\rm i}}{2} {\overline D}{}{\mathbf{u}}, \quad
{\boldsymbol{\lambda}} = {\rm i} \big( \dot {\mathbf{u}} + 2{\rm i} m {\mathbf{u}}   \big), \; {\boldsymbol{\bar\lambda}} = -{\rm i} \big( \mathbf{\dot{\bar{u}}} - 2{\rm i} m {\mathbf{\bar u}}   \big),
\end{eqnarray}
where the flat spinor derivatives $D, {\overline D}{}$ were defined in {(\ref{{cD1}})}. We are dealing with  chiral superfields ${\mathbf{u}}, {\mathbf{\bar u}}$ and, therefore,
the physical component fields may be defined in the usual way as

nexttext:
Thus, the full actions invariant under both the broken $(S)$ and the unbroken $(Q)$ supersymmetries  read
\begin{eqnarray}\label{finactionsR}
S_0 &=& \int dt \big\{  \dot u \dot{\bar u} -  {\rm i} m \big( \dot u \bar u - \dot{\bar u} u  \big) - {\rm i} \big( \dot \psi {\bar\psi}{}- \psi \dot{\bar\psi}{}   \big) - 4 m \psi{\bar\psi}{}  \big\}, {\nonumber} \\
S_{anyon} &=&\int dt \left[{\rm i} \left( \ddot{u}\dot{{\bar u}} -\dot{u}\ddot{{\bar u}}\right)- 8 m \dot{u} \dot{{\bar u}} + 4{\rm i} m^2\left( \dot{u} {\bar u} -u \dot{{\bar u}}\right)  +4 \dot\psi \dot{{\bar\psi}{}} + 8 {\rm i} m \left( \dot\psi {\bar\psi}{} -\psi\dot{{\bar\psi}{}}\right) + 16 m^2 \psi{\bar\psi}{} \right],{\nonumber} \\
S_{rigid} &=& \int dt \left[ \ddot{u} \ddot{{\bar u}} - 2 {\rm i} m \left( \ddot{u}\dot{{\bar u}} -\dot{u} \ddot{{\bar u}}\right)+
4 m^2 \dot{u} \dot{{\bar u}} - {\rm i} \left( \ddot\psi \dot{\bar\psi}{} -\dot\psi \ddot{\bar\psi}{} \right) -8 m \dot\psi\dot{\bar\psi}{} - 4{\rm i} m^2 \left( \dot\psi {\bar\psi}{} -\psi\dot{\bar\psi}{}\right) \right].
\end{eqnarray}

Note that the Newton-Hooke superparticle actions $S_0$ and $S_{anyon}$ may be represented, similarly to the bosonic case, as integrals of the Cartan forms  {(\ref{{SUSYNHooke-forms2}})} taken in the $\theta \rightarrow 0$ limit:

S_{rigid} &=& \int dt \left[ \ddot{u} \ddot{{\bar u}} - 2 {\rm i} m \left( \ddot{u}\dot{{\bar u}} -\dot{u} \ddot{{\bar u}}\right)+
4 m^2 \dot{u} \dot{{\bar u}} - {\rm i} \left( \ddot\psi \dot{\bar\psi}{} -\dot\psi \ddot{\bar\psi}{} \right) -8 m \dot\psi\dot{\bar\psi}{} - 4{\rm i} m^2 \left( \dot\psi {\bar\psi}{} -\psi\dot{\bar\psi}{}\right) \right].
\end{eqnarray}

transformations
text:
$$
\delta_Z u = e^{-2 {\rm i} m t} \, a, \quad \delta_Z {\bar u} = e^{2 {\rm i} m t} \, \bar{a}, \qquad
\delta_T u =\frac{e^{-2 {\rm i} m t} -1}{2m} \, b, \quad \delta_T {\bar u} =\frac{e^{2 {\rm i} m t} -1}{2m} \, \bar{b}.
$$

nexttext:
and, thus, the fermionic terms completing the bosonic actions  to the full supersymmetric ones {(\ref{{finactionsR}})} are determined by their
invariance under  the $S, {\overline S}{}$ and $Q, {\overline Q}{}$ transformations {(\ref{{Qtr}})}, {(\ref{{Str}})}.
\item The action $S_0$ {(\ref{{finactionsR}})} is a some variant of generalized Galileon action (see e.g. \cite{GHJT,KO}). Indeed, the transformations {(\ref{{ZTtr}})}
are some variant of polynomial shift symmetries \cite{GGHY}. They go to the standard Galileon symmetries in the flat $(m \rightarrow 0)$ limit
prevtext:
\item The fermionic components $(\psi, {\bar\psi}{})$ are invariant under the $(Z, {\overline Z}{})$ and $(T, {\overline T}{})$
transformations

<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E65.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\delta_{Z}\psi=\delta_{Z}{\bar{\psi}}{}=0,\qquad\delta_{T}\psi=\delta_{T}{\bar%
{\psi}}{}=0" display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><msub><mi>δ</mi><mi>Z</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mi>ψ</mi></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><msub><mi>δ</mi><mi>Z</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mover accent="true"><mi>ψ</mi><mo stretchy="false">¯</mo></mover></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow><mo rspace="22.5pt">,</mo><mrow><mrow><msub><mi>δ</mi><mi>T</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mi>ψ</mi></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><msub><mi>δ</mi><mi>T</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mover accent="true"><mi>ψ</mi><mo stretchy="false">¯</mo></mover></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mrow></math>

nexttext:
\item Our supersymmetric actions {(\ref{{finactionsR}})} are a supersymmetrization of extended Galileon actions. Of course, these are not really Galileons,
because in one dimension the higher-dimensional terms in the action always produce  higher-order equations of motion. Nevertheless, our
actions possess the proper extension {(\ref{{ZTtr}})} of the Galilean symmetries {(\ref{{ZTtr0}})}. Funnily enough, the simplest harmonic oscillator action {(\ref{{BelNer}})} (as well as its supersymmetric extension) features such a symmetry, and it may be called {\it ``extended Galileon''}.
\item Due to the slightly non-standard reduction we used {(\ref{{rescale2}})}, the actions {(\ref{{an}})} can be represented in terms
of Cartan forms which behave as  Wess-Zumino terms under $(Z,T,S)$ transformations. Performing the first reduction {(\ref{{rescale1}})}, the
forms $\omega_J, \omega_3$ will vanish and, therefore, the proper actions should be constructed in a standard way as  Wess-Zumino terms \cite{GHJT}.
\end{itemize}


\setcounter{equation}{0}
\section{Conclusion}
We have extended our previous analysis of a superparticle moving in flat $D=2{+}1$ spacetime (including higher time derivatives) \cite{kkln} to a superparticle moving on AdS$_3$, with $N{=}(2,0)$, $D{=}3$ supersymmetry partially broken to $N{=}2$, $d{=}1$. We have employed the coset approach to constructing the component actions. The higher time-derivative terms were chosen to preserve all (super)symmetries of the free superparticle in AdS$_3$. The actions have a nice form in terms of covariant Cartan forms. We also considered the nonrelativistic limit, in which
our superalgebra turns into the Newton-Hooke superalgebra extended by two central charges, and the reduced actions describe a Newton-Hooke superparticle including higher derivative terms.

Our consideration was purely classical. To analyze the effects of the higher derivative terms one should quantize the system.
In the present case this is much more complicated than for a superparticle moving in flat $D=2{+}1$ spacetime.
Already the quantization of the nonrelativistic systems constructed here should be quite useful. We are planning to come back to this task in future publications.
